prompt.content:
Here is a conversation between a seeker and a supporter.
supporter:How are you?
seeker:Hello. I am okay. I have been grieving the loss of my grandmother so I've been a little down lately.
supporter:I am so sorry for your loss... When did this happen?
seeker:This happened in May. I had to think about it for a moment because I was thinking it was March. It was May. This year has completely thrown me off. She passed away in May.
seeker:Sorry for sounding redundant. I have just haven't been myself.
supporter:Wow that is horrible, and you don't sound redundant at all.
seeker:Thank you.
supporter:I understand that loss is a painful thing to go through and can take us a while to learn to cope with it.
supporter:I take it you two were close?
seeker:That is true. I know the time will heal but it is painful.
seeker:We were very close when I was younger however for the past 15 or so years she was in a home in a different state.
seeker:I didn't reach out to her much. I regret that.
seeker:I am kind of ashamed that I did not make more of an effort.
supporter:I completely understand that. It is important to be able to let yourself heal.
seeker:That is one of the hard parts for me. I don't take enough time for myself.
supporter:Don't beat yourself up over things that we can't control.
supporter:What do you mean?
seeker:Thank you. That was nice to hear that.
seeker:Sorry if that was confusing. I mean I don't take time for myself to heal because I feel so guilty that I didn't talk to her in the end.
seeker:Should I just accept it?
supporter:I think that you need to understand that  things happen about of our control and to not just accept it and forget it, but maybe put a day aside every year to celebrate her life.
seeker:That is a good idea.
seeker:I do plan on taking a small trip to celebrate her life.
supporter:My grandmother was amazing, and loved burritos, so we used to make them together. After she passed, we started making them as a family in order to celebrate the life she had and memories of her.
seeker:That such a precious memory to have.
supporter:That helps us all remember not her death, but her life and the good memories in a way that would show her how much you do care.
supporter:Do you celebrate Christmas?
seeker:You're right. I think something along those lines would make me feel her death in a different light. Make it into something enjoyable to remember her and not feel guilty. She wouldn't want that. Sometimes it takes an outside view to see. I appreciate your kind words.
seeker:Yes, I do. Do you?
seeker:Merry Christmas!
supporter:I do, Merry Christmas to you too!
seeker:I keep forgetting it's today. This year has just been so different
seeker:Thank you!
supporter:It has been a very different year, I am glad we are nearing the end of it.
seeker:I am glad we are nearing the end of it too.
seeker:I appreciate you being there for me. It was nice to have someone to talk to.
supporter:Is there anything else I can help you with?
seeker:No. You have helped with everything I needed.
seeker:Thank you.
supporter:I understand that I am glad to listen. It helps me just as much.

Here is a conversation between a seeker and a supporter.
supporter:Hello my name is Sharon, how are you today? :)
seeker:Hi Sharon. Am good just concerned about my son.
supporter:Oh I see.  What's happening with your son?
seeker:I suspect my son is in bad company. His most recent behaviour is so different from what I am used to
supporter:Oh that's hard to deal with.   My daughter ran with a bad crowd for a while and I remember the deep worry.
supporter:What sort of behaviour are you noticing?  How old is he?
seeker:My son is 15. Recently he's keeping to himself and mostly stays locked in his room. He barely allows anyone in.
supporter:And when you try and talk to him about it what does he say?
seeker:He says he's studying online. But I suspect he's doing other stuff online apart from study
supporter:Oh I see.  Apart from isolating how is he doing otherwise, like at school?  Is he still seeing his friends at all?
supporter:It can be scary not knowing what our kids are up to online.
seeker:Not really. He just has this one particular friend who comes over sometimes and they lock themselves in the room.
supporter:Hmm.  So a lot of mystery.   I can understand you being worried.   Is he your only child?
seeker:I am so scared I don't want to confront him I have always tried to show him how much I trust him as away to make him feel responsible enough
seeker:Yes. He is my only child and I am single parent
supporter:Thats good parenting!   Perhaps if you frame it as being about you, e.g. "I am getting really worried, can you please explain....it's affecting me (affecting my sleep/work/whatever" .... maybe it will inspire him to be more forthcoming
supporter:Any signs of depression?   I have been depresed before, and self-isolating can be a symptom, I've been there...
seeker:Never thought of it that way. That could be a possibility. But he always seems happy and we chat a lot onlythat he his behind closed doors in his room for a long time everyday.
seeker:Am also concerned about the friend who comes over. I don't really know his family or home just that he's from the neighborhood and they go to the same school.
supporter:Hmm.  My other thought is tell him what you just told me, that you have been trying to show him that you trust him....but be honest and tell him you are afraid.   Hopefully, he won't want you feeling that way, and will open up a bit.
supporter:Yes I can see that being concerning when you know nothing about the friend.   Yet you walk a fine line because he needs the freedom and autonomy to choose his friends without explanation required...it's such a balancing act.   I can tell you that I have raised a daughter, and that teen years were tougher than toddlerhood.   Lots of worry, but she came through it and is fine now.
supporter:I wonder if there is a teacher he is close to that you could bring your concerns to, perhaps the teacher may have some insight about yoru son to offer?
seeker:I find reassurance from your words. Its been tough for me this far we have come with my son and I want us to be close even as he growing up to become a young man. I have a good relationship with their teacher and will definitely give her a friendly call to know more from her.
supporter:Oh good.   And it may be just a normal part of his development.   Teens pull away from parents, peer group becomes far more important.  It may be as simple as that.

seeker:Hello there

seeker:I have tried going to support groups and therapy. I also take medications. Despite this I still feel overwhelmed.
supporter:It sounds like you have tried a lot of different methods, so good for you for taking care of yourself. What is overwhelming you?

supporter:It is a very scary time we are all living through, so it's very easy to understand your higher anxiety with someone you care about maybe facing it. What can you do to feel better?

supporter:That's a great way to approach it-- since the time has to pass anyway, you can use it to take care of yourself and move your life forward despite the "pause" of the pandemic.

supporter:Please take good care of yourself, and I hope your friend stays healthy or gets well very soon.

prompt.content:
Here is a conversation between a seeker and a supporter.
seeker:Hi, I have been feeling a bit down lately. My levels of stress and concern have been higher since the pandemic began.
supporter:Sorry you have been feeling down. What are some strategies you have tried to help you cope?
seeker:Well, I have tried to get my mind off of it by activities at home. Spending time with my family.
supporter:Those sound like positive ways of handling stress. It is natural of course to feel stressed out by the pandemic so it can be useful to think of ways to help manage that stress.
seeker:Yes, but I still seem to struggle with feeling a bit more down than I'd like. Not sure what to do.
supporter:Have you tried meditation and/or deep breathing exercises? I know I find that helpful when I am worrying.
seeker:I have tried meditation before, but quite a bit back. Do you have any activities you could recommend, without risking my health? Maybe in my own home, so that I can social distance.
supporter:One exercise I find helpful is lying on my back with a pillow under my head. I keep my legs bent and put a pillow under my knees for support. I then put one hand on my chest and one on my diaphram and slowly breathe through my nose feeling my stomach press against my hand. I then exhale slowly through my nose and repeat for about 10 minutes. It can be very calming.
seeker:Okay, I will give that a try. I don't feel I'm at a level that I need therapy or medication, so this might be a good way to calm my nerves when I am feeling apprehensive or stressed out.
supporter:Good, I hope that helps. I would also trying to reach out to others who are experiencing the same. It is harder nowadays with covid but there are many online groups. You could even start your own group!
seeker:Yes, I do find that there are times when I am on a social media outlet that it does seem to make me feel better. I can feel humor. But, it can be a bit depressing too. Maybe I should block the ones that have mostly negative posts?
supporter:I hear you on that. Sometimes social media can also be negative. I think that blocking negative posts is a great idea. It is a way of taking control
seeker:I wished I had some more ideas on some fun, interesting or things to fill my time at home. I often feel I get in a bit of a rut with the same thing. Since we are home more now.
supporter:Are there any hobbies that you have been interested in but never had the time for? Or perhaps hobbies that you used to do but have not tried in awhile?
seeker:Well, I used to read quite a bit more, but I have slowed down on it. Maybe I should go and grab a few books. Thanks for the idea!

Here is a conversation between a seeker and a supporter.
supporter:Hello. How are you doing today?
seeker:Hi, I'm struggling today.
supporter:I'm sorry to hear that. Anything in particular that is bothering you?
seeker:I just feel worn out with everything I have to do.
seeker:I don't know what else I can d to help my daughter.
supporter:I understand that you are feeling worn out and don't know what else you can do to help your child. Is there something specific going on or is it just life in general?
seeker:My daughter struggles with school work and memory. She learns differently and needs lots of support. I have contacted the school a number of times over the years but never really had any support or acknowledgement from them. I guess it's just an accumulation of things.
supporter:You have tried hard to help her and that is admirable. Don't beat yourself up and be proud of the things you have done for her.
seeker:But what do I now. She's 17 and it's so difficult to give her the time and then  encourage her to tell me when she needs help and for her to be willing to accept it.
supporter:While I do not have kids, from what I have seen my friends and family do in this situation is try to find something that your daughter is interested in and attempt to build off of that. So instead of her learning to just learn, she is learning something that is relevant to her. Maybe that might spark something in her to come up with her way of learning since traditional methods aren't working.
seeker:That is great advice. She does climb and hasn't been able to climb or see her friends with everything closed. I think as she will be able to again soon may be that will help her to relax and get back into it. She does learn through repetition but has lacked enthusiasm especially in the last few months.
supporter:Having her go climbing more sounds like a good plan. Hopefully things are opening up around you now that the vaccine is becoming more common.
supporter:Repetition is tough. I know I used a lot of flash cards as a way of learning through high-school and college. It's an old method but it can work.
seeker:She had heart  surgery as a baby so has actually had the vaccine herself as she's in the vulnerable category.  I think she ends up spending so long making aide memoires that she then leaves herself so little time to actually study.
supporter:I can imagine after having heart surgery as a baby she wants to live life to it's fullest extent and prioritizes making memories over school. Does she ever talk about what her plans are for after high-school? At some point she will have to connect the dots of having to get a job to be able to go out and have fun, and unfortunately doing OK in school comes with that. That or a vocational school to learn a trade (what I personally did).
seeker:What did you do? Her interests are music and photography. Recently she has started a gardening club with the horticulture department at school. She does enjoy her social life well when she has been able to have it. She has had social ups and downs but apart from the epidemic she has been happier than in her earlier years at school. You are right she is becoming an adult and will find her place. At 17 I guess she doesn't have to decide just yet.
seeker:You have certainly made me feel a bit more positive.
supporter:Sorry for the delay. I am glad you are feeling more positive. I was into cars so I went to vocational school to become an auto mechanic. After a couple years of that I realized I wasn't cut out for physical labor and went to college. But the knowledge from working on cars helped me understand things better at college since I had real world applications I could use it on.

seeker:I do. There is a study group of people in my class. I am preparing really well but I've struggled with this class so much that I still get really worried.
supporter:It sounds like you are preparing well but are still worried that it won't be enough. Does that sound right?
seeker:Yes, that's right. I feel like I could literally study 24 hours a day and it won't be enough. It's hard to know if the information is really getting into my head, and if I'm actually understanding it all.
supporter:Sometimes taking a break and clearing your mind, taking a few deep breaths, can help people calm down. Is that something you can do?
seeker:I have tried that. And it does kind of help in the moment. It's when I get back to studying that all of the anxiety sets in. And it gets worse as it gets closer to the test. If I'm not studying, I feel guilty that I'm taking a break.
supporter:I understand that. I have felt the same way before. But I realized I don't have to feel guilty for taking a break. It's important for my mental health.
seeker:And I try to remember that, too. And I know that's right. But in the moment I feel guilty, so it's so hard for me to relax taking a break.
supporter:Just in the conversation I can see how stressed out you are and struggling with how to handle that.
seeker:Yes. Once my head is in this stressful mode, it's hard to break free.
supporter:Sometimes talking with a close friend can help. Have you tried that?
seeker:I have. And that does help in the moment. It's always when I get back into the actual studying that it's a problem. I think getting the test over with is the only thing that will help.
supporter:It sounds like the actual studying is what is causing you to be stressed. Does that seem to be true?
seeker:Yeah, definitely. I'm just worried about the test.
supporter:I think you have done everything you can to be prepared for the test. And know a few strategies to help you cope with your stress. I think you will feel much better once it's over!
seeker:I agree
\.
supporter:Ok! It sounds like this helped!
seeker:It did - thank you.

prompt.content:
Here is a conversation between a seeker and a supporter.
supporter:Hello! How are you doing today?
seeker:I'm not doing so well. I'm really lonely and kind of sad.
supporter:I'm so sorry to hear that.
supporter:Do you mind me asking what is going on that is making you feel this way?
seeker:Thank you. I broke up with my girlfriend. It was the right thing to do, but now I'm really lonely and sad.
supporter:I'm so sorry to hear that. It sounds to me like you're having a hard time dealing with the emotions that you're dealing with after having broken up with your girlfriend. Does this sound right?
seeker:Yes, that's right. It's been really hard.
supporter:I can tell that you're really struggling.
seeker:Thank you. I was with her for about a year. It was good at first, of course.
supporter:I've dealt with these emotions myself. I recently broke up with my now ex-boyfriend. I have been feeling these same emotions.
seeker:I'm sorry to hear that. How long were you together? The loneliness gets so hard, especially when you just want to tell something to someone.
supporter:I know it feels terrible, but I think that you reaching out for support is a great first step! I'm really proud of you! You will get through this!
seeker:Thank you. Honestly, I'm glad you're there to reach out to.
supporter:We were together for about 5 years. Yes, the loneliness does get very hard.
supporter:I'm happy that I can be here to help you and so that you have someone to talk to! I promise to do my best!
seeker:Oh wow, that's a long time. And thanks. I appreciate your optimism! I am usually very upbeat and optimistic myself.
seeker:Thank you. I really appreciate it. Hopefully I can help you somehow too.
supporter:After my breakup, I found that the best thing to do was to involve myself in other activities that I enjoyed in order to take my mind off of the negative feelings that I was dealing with.
seeker:The shiba inu in my profile circle is making me smile. I used to have a shiba inu. :)
supporter:You seem very kind! I appreciate your willingness to be here for and to listen to me as well!
supporter:Aww! That makes me happy to hear that seeing my profile picture is making you smile!
seeker:That sounds really smart. I've been trying to do that. Of course with a pandemic going on it's more difficult.
supporter:Have you considered getting into any hobbies to take your mind off of what's going on?
seeker:No no... my profile picture. Yours shows up as a squirrel. lol
seeker:I usually hike a lot, but my hiking groups aren't going out right now.
supporter:Oh! I'm so sorry! Haha!
supporter:Have you considered things like journaling, reading, or arts and crafts?
seeker:Maybe I should get a pet squirrel?
seeker:Yes, I actually read and write quite a bit. Especially for work. That's not overly therapeutic, but it helps nonetheless.
supporter:That may not be a bad idea! If you really like them and are able to properly care for it, animals can be very therapeutic!
seeker:I have one dog who isn't much bigger than a squirrel. She has been an invaluable companion.
supporter:Writing and reading have been proven to be extremely therapeutic. I used to write down my feelings on a piece of paper and then destroy it (throw it away) once I was done. There's something about it that really seems to help.
supporter:Aww! That sounds like an adorable dog! What breed of dog is she? I have two cats myself. They make me feel better on a daily basis!
seeker:I've tried to keep a journal but I never stick to it. I find that writing letters to friends serves me the same purpose, and it helps me to stay connected, too. Plus, people love getting real, hand-written mail.
seeker:She is a miniature dachshund. Today she went to the bank with me, and all of the tellers came to the window to look into the car at her. lol  I like cats too. Animals are so healing.
supporter:That sounds like a great idea! I love the fact that it helps you to stay connected, especially considering (as you already mentioned) that it's difficult to connect right now since we're dealing with COVID-19.

seeker:I wish it was easier and okay to travel right now. A trip or a road trip would do me wonders.
seeker:So is five years! I hope everything works out for the best for you, too.
supporter:I completely agree! Where would you go if you were able to right now?

prompt.content:
Here is a conversation between a seeker and a supporter.
supporter:Hello how are you?
seeker:I'm, okay, thanks, and you?  I'm feeling a bit down because I'm alone for the holidays.
supporter:Well that's no good, does your family live far away?
seeker:Yes, my family is scattered all over the country, like Seattle, Georgia, PA.  I'm sure I'm not the only one with no plans this weekend, though.
supporter:True but I can understand that, it is hard being alone at the holidays.
supporter:Did you have plans this weekend?
seeker:No.  My nearby friends all went away for the holidays.  I could probably just occupy my time with things I need or want to do in order to distract myself.
supporter:What kind of hobbies do you have?
seeker:I'm teaching myself the piano.  I'm also teaching myself  how to work a stenography machine for possible future employment as a stenographer.  I also like to read novels.
supporter:I have never understood how those work..I find it amazing someone can type out whole words or sentences with one word
seeker:Yeah, it's pretty cool.  For example, if I hit DRAT in one stroke, then "Did there come a time" will appear in English on my machine's  LCD screen.
supporter:Wow that is crazy, I don't understand how that works, is it preprogrammed or does it go by how the word sounds?
seeker:Each stenographer has their own "Personal Dictionary" which is a list of words in English along with how you in particular write out those words or phrases in steno.  This dictionary is present within the actual steno machine after you transfer it from your laptop to the machine via cable or wifi.  Thus your machine then knows how you write out words in particular and how to translate those words from steno to English - each stenographer writes a little differently.
supporter:OK that makes sense, so you basically program it as the user. I take it your stenography machine becomes pretty close to you lol
supporter:Is this your first holiday alone?
seeker:Yes, exactly!  And it's very important to back up your personal dictionary to the cloud or a seperate drive so that you don't lose it in a hard-drive crash.  A lot of work goes into creating that dictionary!  No, it's happened before, being along for the holidays; but you've helped to cheer me up, so thanks!
supporter:No problem, I hope I have made your day a little better!
seeker:You have, thanks!  Did you do anything special?

supporter:Hi, how are you today?
seeker:Hi there, I'm struggling to be honest.
supporter:What are you struggling with?
seeker:I've been finding it really hard to motivate myself to do anything for the last year or so, but it's been getting worse recently. Everything feels like hard work.
supporter:To be honest, I feel the same way sometimes, too.  It is nice to have someone to talk to about this.  Have you talked to anyone else about this yet?
seeker:I haven't really, I feel like other people have their own issues and I don't want to burden them. It's good that others feel the same. Do you have any advice on what makes you feel better?
supporter:Yes.  I agree.  For me personally, I noticed if I think back of a time before I lost my motivation, sometimes it helps me to reenergize a bit.
supporter:What have motivated you in the past?
seeker:Hmm, I'm finding it hard to remember a time I didn't feel like this! I feel like this has been going on forever! I used to enjoy walking, and generally getting things done around the house. I am also self employed and loved putting time into my business but I've been finding that hard recently.
seeker:I've been watching a lot of Netflix and youtube and not doing much else.
supporter:I have been spending a lot of time home by myself as well.
seeker:How do you cope with it? How do you not get bored and restless?
supporter:I noticed if I try to adhere to a schedule, even a very simple one, such as getting up at a certain time, making breakfast, and showering.  My days tend to go better.
seeker:I've been finding I have a lot of time alone with my thoughts recently.
seeker:That's a good idea, I could try that. At the moment I get up at around 11am but U have been trying to get up earlier but I just can't make myself do it. I've also been sleeping during the day which is maybe not good.
supporter:Have you tried reading?  I find reading motivates me sometimes, too.  Sometimes too much thinking alone leaves me digging a hole for myself.
seeker:I used to get a lot of pleasure from reading and would always have a book on the go. Now reading feels like a chore, as if I am making myself do it.
supporter:I sometimes force myself to exercise when I get sleepy when I shouldn't be tired during the day.
seeker:That's a good idea I could definitely try that.
seeker:I suppose that is a little weather dependant though.
supporter:Maybe try YouTubing?  There are a lot of interesting channels that talks about science, technology, personal health, ... etc.  That can be beneficial to you and worthwhile.

supporter:Yes, the YouTube algorithm is not always the most helpful sometimes.  You can try logging out to see if you see some other recommendations.
seeker:I will do that after this chat, and see if I can find any home workout videos on there.
supporter:I used to be in the military, so I have a rough idea of what exercises I can perform and how much of it I can do each time.  Looking up more information on it is a great idea.

prompt.content:
Here is a conversation between a seeker and a supporter.
seeker:Hello, I have been feeling very overwhelmed with school.
supporter:Hello. I totally understand being stressed out by school. I am currently in a Ph.D. program and it can be overwhelming. Do you have any hobbies to help with your stress?
seeker:I do like to read, but I haven't had enough time. I have been going on walks more frequently.
supporter:It sounds like you do a lot of activities that are solitary. Have you considered maybe partaking in a similar activity, like a book club, where there is more interaction with people?
seeker:No, I did not consider that actually. I do enjoy my alone time since I am so busy and I have a toddler, but maybe doing something more sociable would be good.
supporter:Being busy, especially with having a small child can make you feel lonely, enhancing the stress you feel from school. Participating in social events geared toward your interest might be able to connect you to people with similar feelings!
seeker:I think so too. I never thought of it like that.
supporter:I'm sure that you are trying your best to be both a good student and a great parent. It is understandable that you may not have considered those options.
seeker:Yes I constantly think of my son and family, and I didn't think involving myself in sociable activities
 would be beneficial.
seeker:I figured I really needed some alone time. I didn't realize I could be experiencing loneliness.
supporter:It is so admirable that you are acting so selfless.
supporter:Are you aware of any activities that you can participate in that can include your family? It could be the best of both worlds.
seeker:Yes, we like to go swimming at the YMCA together.
supporter:That is great! Physical activity has been shown to reduce stress levels.
supporter:My sister-in-law really benefits from having her sons in sports. She is able to connect with the other team moms and considers them some of her best friends. Depending on your YMCA your son may be able to participate in some of their programs?
seeker:Yes, and swimming is great exercise.
seeker:And if we do that more we can spend more time together.
seeker:I have been looking into putting him in soccer.
seeker:He can start at 3 years old.
supporter:Soccer would be a perfect way for both you and your son to interact with other people of similar interests.
seeker:I think so too. You gave me a lot to think about today that I didn't consider before.
supporter:I am glad to help, Hopefully, considering these options will not only reduce your stress from being busy with being a parent and with school, but it will also bring you closer to your child.
seeker:Yes, and both of those are major goals of mine. But the stress sometimes feels inevitable.
supporter:Sometimes stress is inevitable. You just have to know how to channel it. Some use physical activity, others use journaling. These seem to be outlets you can consider?
seeker:The physical activity for sure.
seeker:I do so much writing with my Master's program. Sometimes I feel like my hand will fall off.
supporter:Physical activity seems to be the option you are most interested in.

supporter:Hi, how are you? What would you like to discuss today?
seeker:Hello my name is Marie
seeker:I have a lot of depression
seeker:I feel like I'm always hurting
supporter:Hi, Marie. You are dealing with depression. I'm sorry to hear that.
seeker:I have low energy most of the time except for when I'm working
supporter:What is it about work that gets you going?
seeker:My job is fast paced I work for a call center working from home
supporter:You spend a lot of your day talking and interacting with people. Do you enjoy the work?
seeker:I'm always taking one call after the other and barely got time to think about my problems I'm dealing with
seeker:I enjoy my job
supporter:The work distracts you from your problems but it does not give you time to address them.
seeker:I feel like I get to help alot of people
seeker:it distracts me from my problems exactly
supporter:I'm sure you do! Phone support requires a lot of patient explanation. That is challenging for many people.
seeker:I'm actually one of the best at my job
seeker:I wish I was that good with myself personally
supporter:I'm glad you have found success and fulfillment at your work.
seeker:Thank you
supporter:If your job is good for you, what do you think makes you feel depressed then?
seeker:I don't know what I'm going to myself when I'm not working
seeker:I feel hopeless about many things
supporter:Exercise? Reading? School? Friends?
supporter:Hopelessness might be something that you have learned because you have expectations.
supporter:Do you feel that there has to be some sort of result? Progress? Improvement?
seeker:trying to lose weight, trying to void getting diabetes, having better conversation with boyfriend , convince him to spend more time with me instead of work buddies after work hours, want to finish college, being able to buy a house, improving my credit, convincing my dad and brother to get mental help
supporter:If you didn't do any of those things ever, how would you feel about yourself?
seeker:having a more active lifestyle , 
making new friends
seeker:those are things I need to accomplish
supporter:Now imagine you achieve all of those things, and you do so in spectacular fashion. Would you be happy? Or would you find another reason to feel hopeless?
seeker:I believe those are the things that have been bothering me for a long time
seeker:not being able to accomplish those things makes me feel hopeless
seeker:frustrated
seeker:feel like I'm meaningless to thers
supporter:It's important to remember that you choose what goals to pursue. You decide the criteria for success and failure. You are the final arbiter of your life.
seeker:those are all goals in my life that I need to reach
seeker:I just don't know how most of the time
supporter:I understand. We all have goals. Goals can be helpful. But ask yourself why you chose those particular goals.
seeker:I feel like I can't get guidance anywhere
seeker:those are goals that when I accomplish them it will make me feel better
supporter:It sounds like you need someone to tell you what to do, or to give you permission to do what you want to do.
seeker:if I accomplish them it will feel like there was improvement
seeker:probably I've been used to my dad telling me what to do for a long time
seeker:I lack self motivation
supporter:If you need permission, I hereby grant you permission to pursue what is meaningful to you.
supporter:You gave me a list of things that you want to achieve. Pick one.
seeker:I want to do
 all those
seeker:I'm not sure what should I do first
supporter:I understand. Which one is more important. Which is the one you can do right away? Also: which one do you really *not* want to do?
seeker:I feel like all those goals will take some time
seeker:can't be accomplish right away
supporter:Of course. Anything worthwhile takes time.
seeker:I need to stay on top of those goals but I feel like I get side tracked
supporter:You feel compelled to pursue these goals. Why? If you don't, what is the worst that could happen? What if you only pursued one goal?
seeker:pursuing only one of these will not be enough to make me happy I will keep thinking about the goals I need to accomplish
supporter:You need to readjust your expectations, which are causing you to feel unhappy.
seeker:is there a technique that you can suggest I follow to feel self motivated and keep my goals organized and in check
seeker:I will feel successful after completing most of these goals

supporter:Did you find that your normal coping mechanisms were not as helpful today?
seeker:Yeah, December has been hard on everyone. I know things will get better but its hard finding positivity when I feel so negative.
supporter:Sounds like your support is not appreciated.
seeker:Usually coping is either eating a ton of food or smoking marijuana, but with the holiday money is tight. I am listening to emo pop music from the 2000's now to help.
supporter:Music definitely helps!
supporter:I have a list of songs that I like to sing to. I can't really sing, like, at all. But I love to do it. And it makes me forget about whatever is going on.
seeker:Honestly, in the past I have been a lot lower than I am now. I really just hope I am able to stay strong for as long as i can right now
seeker:Honestly i do the same thing a lot. Songs with a lot of emotion that i can belt out
supporter:You are certainly self-aware. Better off than most people!
seeker:i will have to find somewhere i can properly exercise my awful vocals lol
supporter:Ah! I like pop songs from the 60's :-)
supporter:Ha! The car is always good!
seeker:honestly its because i have been hospitalized due to my mental state. i try to be as self aware as possible now. i just hate the feeling of being blindsided.
supporter:Have you tried The Smiths? Band from the 80's. They are my go to for when I am feeling low.
seeker:i will give the throwbacks a try today. I do get down with a few of the older bands thats for sure
supporter:To be blindsided is a violation of trust.
supporter:Have you spoken to her about it at all, or is that not your jam?
supporter:It's ok. A lot of people are non-confrontational. Society tells us we should be able to express our boundaries. Not everyone is comfortable with that and that is ok.
seeker:we literally just talked about it an hour ago. she says she doesnt know what she wants and she doesnt know how long but she doesnt want to be away from me right now. which i feel just isnt fair. i feel like no one can just pick and choose when they want someone around.
supporter:But that puts more responsibility on you for your feelings. Sounds like you have coping skills for that.
seeker:i know. with COVID this is so much harder. i may just take a long walk and try to focus on myself, because it seems like our future is in flux and it seems like it could go either way.
supporter:You're right. That is not fair. You are feeling conflict and abandoned/not-abandoned.
supporter:Could you make the decision?
seeker:i feel like what i may do, is just sleep on the couch for now and give her as much space as possible, at least for now i think
supporter:Only you are responsible for you. I was with someone who, although we had great fun together, he couldn't be with me as much as I wanted him to. And it made me feel bad. Because it brought up feelings from when I was growing up and neglected.
supporter:It took a long time, and it ...wasn't a clean break. I just got tired of feeling bad, and the relationship just waned.

seeker:Hello there.
supporter:Good evening . How can I help you

seeker:She has been having a problem with a different friend for years. I have been listening to these problems for all of that time. And even though it's so frustrating, because it's the same problem over and over again, I keep listening because she's my friend. But lately I have been going through a lot, and I haven't had as much time to sit and listen to these same problems, and she gets so angry telling me I don't care about her. The problems I've been going through are very serious, and I just don't have time to sit on the phone listening to the same stuff I've been dealing with for years.
supporter:I can understand how angry unappreciated and burnt out you must be feeling.  I would feel that way too
seeker:It's been really rough. I've tried so hard to be there for her, and I feel like she just doesn't even appreciate it.
supporter:I don't think she is a place to be able to see anyone but herself. She is self centereed self asbored and self pity party and doesn't care about anyone but herself right now . Is that accurate?
seeker:Yes, that's exactly accurate. And she is 50 years old, and the issues have all been high school type problems that I've been listening to. Stuff about how she didn't post on social media about her birthday, and little petty things like that. Not something an adult should be concerned with. And I still sat and listened to her all that time.
supporter:I completely understand how unappreciated and stressed this would make you or any person. Especially when our plate is full and its the same old same old and nothing is changing. Its like thinking doing same thing over and over you will get a different result when 2+2 equals 4
seeker:Yes, exactly.
supporter:You are an extremely good and loyal friend and I am so proud of you. Most people would have left her.
seeker:Thank you. That's really important to me. She was starting to convince me that I wasn't a good friend because I wasn't there for her right now when I had problems of my own. Real problems - like my daughter's engagement breaking up.
supporter:However, it is time to take the hard road. YOu are going to have to say with LOVE because its not always what you say but how you say it.  Give me a minute to please type it
seeker:Okay, thank you.
supporter:You are going to have to sit her down and say  I need to be honest with you.  I have always been there for you but you are not willing to take my advice or others advice and quite frankly I just can't do it anymore. IF you want to remain friends I need you to grow up and realize the world doesn't revolve around you or even me.  Right now I could really use a good friend. I am going thru A LOT OF Sh** and I don't need this in my life. So
seeker:I think that's a good idea. I'll try that.
supporter:if you aren't able to do that than I am afraid until you can be a true friend and not just a user than I need to end this friendship . I don't want to but I need to for my mental health and for myself and even for you.  I say this because I love you and I do care but this has become toxic
seeker:Yeah, I like that. I think it's a good idea to say those things to her.
supporter:she really needs to hear it and it sounds toxic to me . I know I wouldn't want a friend to accuse me of not being there and from the chat look like its all about her and she s acting like a spoiled brat
seeker:I agree. She can't see past her own issues to see the whole situation.
supporter:If you think its a more serious problem maybe ask her to seek professional help.
seeker:I might try that if this doesn't work. Thank you for your help.
